course.description: This course targets students who have learned the most basic knowledge in physics in high school. Students with more advanced physics background should consider taking PHYS 1314. reviews.author: Doraemon
reviews.comment_content:
The course mainly covers Chapter 21 to 36 of the textbook, Sears & Zemansky's University Physics with Modern Physics (14th edition, by Young and Freedman). Topics covered include:

Chapter 21. Electric Force and Electric Field
Chapter 22. Gauss Law
Chapter 23. Electric Potential and Electric Potential Energy
Chapter 24. Capacitor and Dielectrics
Chapter 25. Current, Resistance and Voltage
Chapter 26. Kirchhoff's Laws of Circuit and RC circuits
Chapter 27. Magnetic Field and Magnetic Force
Chapter 28. Sources of Magnetic Field
Chapter 29. Electromagnetic Induction
Chapter 30. Inductor
Chapter 31. LRC circuit with an AC power supply
Chapter 32. Light as an Electromagnetic Wave
Chapter 33. Polarization and Scattering
Chapter 35. Young's Double Slit Interference and Thin Film Interference
Chapter 36. Single Slit and Multiple Slit Diffraction, Diffraction Grating and Rayleigh Criterion

[Remark: Chapter 34 is not covered in this semester.]

Comments:
The content is almost the same (perhaps slightly more than) that covered in former HKALE Physics. While some of the topics (such as the magnetic field produced by an infinite straight wire, Ohm's Law, etc.) have already been covered in HKDSE Physics, the same formulas and concepts are introduced in a slightly more rigorous and logical way. Some concepts are even redefined or reformulated using the language of vector operations. Thus, DO NOT simply skip the materials because you have learnt them in high school.

Moreover, since the course content is almost identical to the former HKALE Physics, and midterm and finals are all MCs, I feel that doing HKALE Physics MC past paper by topics is a better way of studying than doing textbook exercises. (While the midterm and final covers a greater range of difficulty than HKALE Physics, you can get about 80% of the score in midterm and final if you can do and understand most HKALE Physics MCQs.)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Leung's teaching is excellent. I can basically understand most, if not all, the concepts taught in lectures without much difficulty, and this greatly reduces my time for self-studying and revising after lectures.

The TA is also great. First, she prepares a 4-slide summary for each and every chapter for each tutorial. Her summary contains useful formulas, making it a good reference for doing Mastering Physics as well as preparing for exams. (Since different TAs are responsible for different tutorial sessions, the above comment is only applicable for the TA in my session.)

reviews.comment_content:
Lots of content, but you’re only scratching the surface of electromagnetism. Quite challenging for students who are not devoted to physics.

I think the things taught in class are more difficult than the things that were asked in the exam. The classes were interesting and rich in content, but the concepts require time to digest, not to mention absorbing and mastering it. So to attain a good grade, you have to spend more time comprehending the theories and making it appear to be physically intuitive to you.

In this course, various mathematical techniques will be introduced, though they were not in the exam. Apart from basic integration and differentiation, the professor will briefly teach about line integrals, phasor diagrams, complex planes and partial derivatives. Mathematical abilities and theories are not emphasized in this course, so these do not commonly show up in the exam. However, understanding the derivation is very good for learning the concepts.

reviews.title: Difficult content, high workload, easy exam
reviews.comment_content:
E&M and optics. Both of them are very difficult topics. However, both the midterm and final exam is set rather easy. If you finish all the HW understanding everything, you'll get a pretty good score.
It helps to have PHYS1112 background since L-R-C circuit is similar to SHM but for most other topics, you can take PHYS1114 without PHYS1112 but only do so if you're ok with calculus and interested in E&M. You need not worry about L-R-C circuit too much as the problems in the exam about LRC is relatively simple, mostly conceptual problems with not much calculations.
My advice for people who want to take this course is to actually finish all homework on your own. It's going to take some time. I know some people who get sources and try to finish the HW. This way is not going to work unless you have the ability to finish the HW on your own, otherwise, seek help from TA or your classmates and make sure you understand every question in the problem set before proceeding. Then, you'll find PHYS1114 much more manageable. Don't let things build up or I can imagine students getting frustrated.

reviews.title: What a letdown.
reviews.comment_content:
Since the content is basically the same as those in past years, here I would like to comment on the experience arrangements in this course conducted online in more detail.

As said in the title, it is quite frankly a disappointment. Many of our us did not complain in the final exam of 2019-20 Fall, because we are either trying to familiarize ourselves with the arrangements, or did not have the chance to do so. I personally find it inconvenient and unfair compared to those taking this course in future or past years, given the online arrangement seals many of the exam strategies, forcing us to do the test question-by-question. More than 1/5 of the students have tried to reason with the instructors on Canvas, and this is their response:

"Dear all,

You may have noticed the heated discussion among some of your fellow students on Canvas, and even received email on the related topic. We believe we should explain our stance and  the rationale behind it.

The obvious reason is to make cheating difficult. Not that we assume every student would cheat, but you certainly will feel uncomfortable if people around you cheat easily. In our current online setting, there is no single method that can stop cheating completely. That's why we need to implement various rules, including scrambling question order, choices, and numbers, etc. The no-going-back rule is just one of them. Cheating cannot easily be prevented by simply pointing camera to the screen. You certainly don't want everyone to look at your screen while you enter your answer.

On the other hand, we fully understand that the no-going-back rule may create additional stress to some students. In respect to those concerns, we have adopted several adjustments to the exam, aiming to ease the stress you may have . Compared to previous terms, we have made the exam open-book (we believe you welcome this) with the same difficulty level as that in closed-book exam, and reduced the number of problems from 30 to 24, to give you extra time on each question.  Also, we will announce not only the total number of questions, but also the number of MCs and non-MCs. We are trying hard to strike a balance between reducing your stress and fencing off academic dishonesty. Some may not like the rule, but the same rule is uniformly applied to each of your 270 fellow students. It is a rule to practice fairness for all students, rather than to target any individual.  By implementing multiple rules, we strive to give our students the confidence that the score each student receive is commensurate to their understanding of the physics by making effort, instead of otherwise. All you need to do is to try your best!

Finally, we would like to remark that many standardized tests, such as SAT, TOEFL and GRE, have this no-going-back rule. You better be aware of it if you need to take these exams in the future.

Best regards,
All instructors of PHYS 1114"

The instructors have made clear that they are intent on preventing anyone from cheating using this method. I'm not saying this is a reckless decision, but they should also consider students' situations as well. Under the rule, many of us can no longer do the same things as we did in a paper examination, such as skipping or double-checking. It can be inconvenient for us during calculation. They should try putting themselves in our shoes instead of going their own ways.

My final message is that, if you are not trying to fulfill your major requirements, I'd suggest taking this course at a later time (i.e. when the pandemic is over) for a more justified arrangement. It is not a fair game for students as a whole when it is changed online. If you are intent on eliminating any cheating, there is one way I could suggest for all courses whereas possible: change the final exam into a final assignment, so nobody has to worry about anything.

reviews.author: Roy Sukjin Mun
reviews.title: A mediocre general physics class
reviews.comment_content:
General physics level electricity and magnetism + interference and diffraction for this semester (Contents vary every semester. Please check which ones are omitted/included).

I recommend reading the course reference (University Physics by Freedman) and Fundamentals of Physics by Halliday. Interested students can also read Electricity and Magnetism by Purcell (some problems are good, but some other problems toward the end, which seems to be added later on by the second writer, are infuriating to read + strangely worded, and seems to be made by a non-physicist.) or Introduction to Electrodynamics by Griffiths for fun. However, the two references mentioned in the beginning should be more than enough.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Overall the teaching was ok.

The professor does address all the course syllabus and which ones are to be excluded for the semester. He may also note whether the contents in his lecture notes will appear in the exams. However, attending the lectures was very inefficient as professor Leung spent most of the time (including the lecture notes) solving examples/talking about contents directly copied from the textbook.

Professor Leung does not give adequate explanations. For instance, he mentioned the direction of a field is uniquely defined by symmetry, but he does not explain why it is so. The concept is in fact abstract and not that intuitive after all. In such cases, it is a good idea to ask questions immediately, as there can be too many people asking the professor after the class.

As a side note, he seems to believe in the survival of the fittest. To quote "Do not sit next to people who cannot answer your question".
reviews.comment_grading:
Fair.

Final is 60 percent, Mid-Term is 30 percent, and the Webwork is 10 percent of the total grade.

In this semester, Mid-Term can be relatively easy just by comprehensively studying the course reference (Though I only read Purcell and Griffiths. But as I said, Freedman/Halliday alone is more than enough for this course).

Final had about 5 questions directly copied from the tutorial work. One can attain an above average grade (A+ range) if he/she has a solid foundation. I have been told that the Final was somewhat difficult for students who have not studied physics prior to taking this class.
reviews.comment_workload: The only assignments are Webwork. However, it is suggested that students study regularly if they have not sufficiently learned general physics prior to taking the class. Attendance is not a mandatory, but the tutorials are very helpful. Depending on the difficulty of the exams, chances are, one may encounter identical/similar questions from the tutorial sessions.
